Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breaths. My buddy sounds genuinely frustrated and confused right now. I can hear the exhaustion in his voice, that "why am I the bad guy?" tone. He feels like he's being logical, offering practical solutions, and getting hit with an emotional wall. He's seeing it as a simple math problem: calories in vs. calories out. And from that perspective, he's right – you can eat "healthy" foods but still consume too many calories to lose weight. That's just how it works.

But... and this is a big but... weight, body image, and food are rarely *just* a simple math problem for most people, especially when there are underlying emotional components involved. His girlfriend's constant complaints about her body, even though he's telling her he finds her sexy, is a huge red flag. It suggests her struggles aren't purely about wanting to be a specific size; there might be deeper insecurities or emotional connections to food at play.

My buddy's approach, while factually accurate from a caloric standpoint, seems to be missing the emotional context entirely. He sees himself as the helpful, truth-telling expert, armed with his own successful weight loss experience. But to her, in that moment, his "objective facts" likely felt like judgment and criticism, especially after he'd already agreed *not* to comment while she was eating. Even if he waited until the end of the day, the entire exercise of her "proving" she ate healthy, followed by his breakdown of the calorie count, probably felt like a setup. He became the "calorie police," and that can feel incredibly shaming, regardless of his intentions.

He's also bringing up the financial contribution, which, while a separate point about their relationship dynamics, feels like it's being used here to bolster his argument that he's supportive and therefore shouldn't be seen as the bad guy. It's almost like he's saying, "Look at all I do for you, financially and with this weight thing, and you still blame me." That connection, while perhaps true for him, probably isn't helping the conversation about her body image and food choices.

He feels unappreciated and misunderstood. He feels like he's the only one willing to be direct and honest, and that honesty is being punished. He's seeing everyone else as enablers, and himself as the brave, but embattled, truth-teller. It's a tough spot to be in, feeling like your genuine efforts to help are being misinterpreted and rejected. But his perspective is very focused on the *what* (calories) and not the *how* (the emotional delivery and the underlying reasons for her struggles).
# They're thinking & feeling 
His girlfriend is likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and defensive right now. She's already expressed insecurity about her weight, and deciding to try and lose it is a big step that requires a lot of emotional energy. When she complains about her body, she might be looking for reassurance and validation, which my buddy seems to be giving her verbally ("I find you sexy"). But when she decided to actively pursue weight loss, she probably wanted support in a way that felt encouraging, not like she was being constantly evaluated.

When she agreed to let him see what she ate, even with the "no comments while eating" rule, there was likely a part of her that wanted to prove him wrong, to show him she *was* eating healthy and *should* be losing weight. She might genuinely believe that eating foods labeled "healthy" is enough, without fully grasping the caloric density or portion control aspect. Her understanding of "healthy eating" might be different from his, focusing on the *type* of food rather than the *quantity*.

When he presented the calorie breakdown, even calmly, it likely felt like a confirmation of her worst fears and insecurities. It probably landed as "See? You *are* doing it wrong. You're eating too much." The fact that he tied it back to his own caloric needs, as a taller, heavier, more active man, probably felt like an unfair comparison and highlighted the perceived difference between them, potentially exacerbating her feelings of inadequacy.

She's probably feeling shamed and judged, despite his intentions. His "objective facts" might have felt like an attack on her efforts and her understanding of nutrition. Her getting "super pissed" is probably a defense mechanism – a way to lash out and protect herself from feeling like a failure. She might feel like he's not truly supporting her, but rather monitoring and criticizing her. The focus on calories, while technically correct, might feel overly simplistic and dismissive of the emotional challenges she faces with food and her body. She likely feels misunderstood and invalidated in her struggle.
# My response 
"Hey man, thanks for calling and laying that out. I can totally hear how frustrating and confusing this is for you. It sounds like you're really trying to be supportive and help her get what *she* says she wants, and it feels like your efforts are just backfiring, right?"

[Pause for him to agree or elaborate]

"Okay, so, look, you're absolutely right about the calories. Objectively speaking, if you're taking in more than you're burning, weight loss isn't going to happen, regardless of how 'healthy' the individual foods are. That's just science, and I get why you'd want to point that out. And it's tough when you've had your own success and you see a clear path, and someone you care about seems to be missing it."

"But here's the thing, man. For a lot of people, especially when there's already insecurity around weight and body image, food and eating are tied up with a *lot* of emotions. When you pointed out the calorie count, even calmly, after agreeing not to comment while she was eating, how do you think that might have landed for her, given how she already feels about her body?"

"It sounds like she's feeling really vulnerable about this, and maybe when you bring up the numbers, it just triggers those insecurities and feels like criticism, even if that's not your intention. It's like she hears 'You're eating too much and that's why you're not losing weight,' and it just confirms her own negative self-talk."

"Instead of focusing on the numbers right now, which seems to be causing conflict, maybe the support she needs looks a little different. Maybe it's more about focusing on *how* she feels, what triggers her to snack, or finding ways to move her body that she actually enjoys. It's less about being the calorie expert and more about being her partner in this, acknowledging that it's tough, and helping her explore the *why* behind some of her eating habits, not just the *what*."

"It's a tricky balance because you want to be honest and helpful, but sometimes the 'help' that's needed isn't just factual information. It's emotional support and understanding. How do you think you could approach this from a place of 'I'm here with you in this struggle' rather than 'Here's the data showing why you're not succeeding'?"
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is a really delicate situation. On one hand, I completely understand where my buddy is coming from—he's frustrated because he's putting in effort to support his girlfriend, both emotionally and financially, and it feels like she's rejecting his help despite saying she wants to lose weight. He's not wrong about the calorie math either; objectively, she's consuming maintenance calories for someone much larger and more active than she is. But I can also see how his approach might be coming across as critical or condescending, even if that's not his intent.  

What stands out to me is the emotional dynamic here. His girlfriend is clearly struggling with body image and self-esteem, and her defensiveness suggests she feels judged or shamed, even if he's just stating facts. The fact that she set a boundary ("don't make comments on what I'm eating as I'm eating it") tells me she's hypersensitive to perceived criticism, which makes sense if she's already feeling insecure. His frustration is valid, but he might be missing that she's not just resisting logic—she's reacting emotionally.  

I also notice a bit of a power imbalance here: he's fit, financially carrying more weight in the relationship, and now he's positioning himself as the "truth-teller" in contrast to everyone else who "enables" her. That could easily make her feel like he's the authority figure in her life, not her partner. Even if he's right about the calories, the way he's framing it ("I'm the only one willing to tell the truth") might come off as self-righteous, which isn't helping.  

Ultimately, this isn't just about weight loss—it's about how they communicate, how she feels supported (or not), and whether he can separate "being right" from "being effective." He might need to step back and ask himself: Is proving his point more important than her feeling understood?
# They're thinking & feeling 
For the girlfriend, this is deeply personal. She's already struggling with her body image, and every conversation about food or weight probably feels like an attack, even if it's framed as "help." When her boyfriend points out her calorie intake, she likely hears: "You're doing this wrong, and I know better." That’s triggering because it reinforces her fear that she’s failing at something she’s already insecure about.  

She might also feel like her efforts are being dismissed. To her, eating a salad and a veggie burrito *feels* like "eating healthy," even if the calories don’t align with weight loss. When he corrects her, it doesn’t feel like support—it feels like nitpicking. She set that boundary ("no comments while I'm eating") because she wants to feel safe, not monitored.  

There’s probably some resentment bubbling under the surface too. He’s financially supporting her more, which can create pressure (even if unspoken) to meet his expectations. Combine that with him being in great shape while she’s struggling, and it’s easy to see why she might feel insecure or even resentful. She might think: "He has it easy, he doesn’t get how hard this is for me."  

At the end of the day, she wants to feel loved and accepted as she is, not like a project to be fixed. Even if she says she wants to lose weight, what she might really want is reassurance that she’s enough—and right now, his "help" might not feel like that.
# My response 
"Man, I hear how frustrated you are. You’re trying to help, and it feels like she’s rejecting it or even blaming you for her lack of progress. That’s gotta hurt, especially when you’re putting so much into the relationship. But I wonder if she’s hearing something different than what you’re trying to say.  

When she talks about her weight, she’s probably not just looking for solutions—she’s looking for emotional support. Like, she might need to vent without feeling like she’s being graded on her choices. Even if you’re right about the calories, pointing it out might make her feel like you’re scrutinizing her, not standing with her.  

Maybe instead of focusing on the numbers, you could ask her: *‘What kind of support would actually feel helpful to you right now?’* She might say she just wants encouragement, or maybe she’d prefer you cook together instead of tracking her meals. If she feels like you’re on her team, she might be more open to your advice later.  

And bro—I get that you’re the ‘truth-teller,’ but sometimes being right isn’t as important as being kind. If she feels judged, she’s gonna shut down. You don’t have to enable her, but you might need to meet her where she’s at emotionally before the practical stuff can even land."  

I’d also gently remind him that relationships aren’t about keeping score (financially or otherwise). If he’s feeling resentful about paying more bills, that’s a separate conversation—mixing it into this one will only make her feel more defensive. The goal isn’t to ‘win’ the argument; it’s to figure out how to support each other without resentment building up.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-24)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a user who is venting about a friendship conflict, where the user is not entirely innocent and has delivered a hurtful comment. The challenge is to balance empathy, validation, and gentle challenge, while also respecting the user's stated desire not to be lectured. 

Deepseek-v3-0324's response is notably more nuanced and layered. In the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, Deepseek-v3-0324 demonstrates a deep internal analysis, recognizing the user's frustration, the escalation, and the underlying respect issues. They also consider the friend's possible insecurities and the broader social context. Deepseek-v3-0324 is careful to acknowledge the user's feelings, but also flags the problematic nature of the 'poor' comment, and explores the power dynamic and privilege at play. Their response is validating but not sycophantic, and they offer both a boundary-setting option and permission to end the friendship, while cautioning against further escalation. 

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, while empathetic and validating, is more surface-level. Their internal monologue is less detailed, and while they recognize the escalation and the hurtfulness of the 'poor' comment, they are more focused on supporting the user's venting and less on challenging or deepening the user's self-reflection. Their response is supportive and pragmatic, but less insightful and less tailored to the deeper dynamics at play. 

On empathy, Deepseek-v3-0324 goes further in understanding both parties' emotional states and motivations. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-v3-0324 offers more actionable, nuanced options. On depth of insight, Deepseek-v3-0324's analysis is richer, especially regarding power dynamics and the subtext of the conflict. On social dexterity, Deepseek-v3-0324 balances validation and gentle challenge more skillfully. On emotional reasoning, Deepseek-v3-0324 demonstrates a more sophisticated understanding of the emotional drivers. On validation/challenging, Deepseek-v3-0324 validates but also gently challenges, whereas Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more purely validating. On message tailoring, Deepseek-v3-0324 is more attuned to the user's stated needs and emotional state. Overall, Deepseek-v3-0324 displays higher EQ across the board.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend is venting, and it sounds like she's feeling a mix of frustration, defensiveness, and maybe a little bit of self-justification. She's clearly annoyed by her friend's repeated comments about the laundry program. It makes sense – having someone constantly critique a personal choice, especially one that seems quite normal within her university's context, would be grating. She's framed the laundry program as a convenience she can afford and enjoys, and the friend's comments feel like an attack on that.

What's interesting is the escalation in the conversation. The initial comments were judgmental about the cost, but the friend's response moved from a simple explanation ("Why would I do something I don't want to?") to a direct jab about the friend's financial status ("she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not"). While my friend states it's "just a fact," it's also undeniably a pointed and likely hurtful comment. It feels like she was pushed to her limit by the friend's persistent negativity and lashed out.

She's asking if she should still be friends with this person, but the way she's describing the situation and her feelings suggests she's already leaning towards distancing herself. She explicitly says the unwanted comments make her "like her less." The fact that she mentions the friend has "few friends" and wonders if this behavior is why, indicates she's already evaluating the friend's social behavior and finding it problematic beyond just their interactions. She's not just looking for validation of her choice to use the laundry program; she's looking for validation of her negative feelings towards the friend and perhaps permission to end the friendship.

The "don't want a lecture, just wanted to vent" part is important. It tells me she's not necessarily looking for advice on how to fix the situation or improve the friendship. She wants to be heard and understood in her annoyance. I need to be mindful of that in my response. I shouldn't jump to telling her she was wrong to call her friend poor, even though that's a definite red flag in the interaction. My focus should be on acknowledging her feelings and the situation she's described.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Based on what my friend has shared, her friend seems to be grappling with some form of envy or insecurity related to money and convenience. Her constant fixation on the laundry program suggests it's not just about the laundry itself, but what it represents: disposable income, ease, and perhaps a different lifestyle than her own.

Her friend likely sees the laundry program as an unnecessary luxury, a "waste of money" that someone with financial constraints wouldn't even consider. Her repeated comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that") probably stem from her own financial reality and potentially a feeling of resentment that others have the ability to afford such conveniences while she doesn't. She might genuinely believe it's a bad financial decision, projecting her own values and circumstances onto others.

The fact that "almost everyone" my friend knows uses the program could make the friend feel even more isolated or "different" in her perspective. Her comments might be a way of trying to find validation for her own choices (doing her own laundry to save money) or to subtly criticize those who can afford not to. It’s a way of saying, "I'm being smart and responsible with my money, unlike you."

When my friend called her "poor," it likely hit a raw nerve. While my friend sees it as a simple statement of fact, for her friend, it probably felt like a deeply personal insult and a confirmation of her own perceived financial limitations. It would have felt like a direct attack on her worth or status, especially since she was likely already feeling sensitive about the topic. Her fury is probably a reaction to feeling exposed, shamed, and defensive. She was likely trying to make my friend feel bad about spending money, and instead, my friend turned the focus back on her own situation, which was a painful blow.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all of this with me. It sounds incredibly frustrating to have someone constantly pick at something like that, especially when it's a choice you're happy with and that's pretty common where you are. I can totally understand why those comments would start to wear on you and make you feel less positively about the friendship.

It's tough when you feel like you're being judged for your choices, even if they seem perfectly reasonable to you. And having someone repeatedly bring it up like that, it's bound to get under your skin. It makes sense that you're wondering about the friendship when her behavior is making you feel this way.

Ultimately, whether or not you want to continue being friends with her is completely up to you. Friendships should add to your life, not constantly drain you or make you feel bad. If her comments are consistently making you feel worse and you're liking her less because of it, that's a really valid reason to re-evaluate things. You don't owe anyone your friendship, especially if it's not a positive dynamic for you.

Maybe take some space if you need to, or just keep interactions brief for a while. See how you feel without that constant commentary. Whatever you decide, know that I hear you, and it's okay to prioritize your own peace and well-being in your relationships.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can see why you’re frustrated. It’s annoying when someone fixates on something that’s none of their business, especially when it’s a personal choice that doesn’t affect them at all. The laundry program is clearly a convenience you value, and her constant comments come across as judgmental and unnecessary. It’s one thing to have an opinion, but to repeatedly bring it up unprompted feels like she’s trying to shame you or assert some kind of moral superiority—like she’s “better” because she does her own laundry. That’s exhausting.  

At the same time, I can’t ignore the way you responded. Calling her “poor” was harsh, even if it’s technically true. Financial differences are a sensitive topic, and throwing that in her face probably felt like a low blow, especially if she’s already insecure about it. It sounds like you were fed up and wanted to shut her down, but now she’s hurt, and the dynamic between you two has shifted.  

What stands out to me is that this isn’t just about laundry—it’s about respect. She doesn’t respect your choices, and you don’t respect her financial situation. That’s a recipe for a toxic friendship. The fact that she has few friends might explain why she’s so fixated on this; maybe she’s socially awkward or struggles with boundaries. But that doesn’t excuse her behavior, and it doesn’t mean you have to tolerate it.  

I also wonder if there’s more to her reaction. Maybe she’s envious that you can afford this luxury, or maybe she feels left out because “almost everyone” uses the program. That doesn’t justify her comments, but it might explain them. Still, if she can’t express her feelings in a healthier way, that’s on her.  

Ultimately, you’re not obligated to stay friends with someone who annoys you or makes you feel judged. But if you do want to salvage this, there’s room for a conversation about boundaries. If not, it might be time to distance yourself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is likely feeling a mix of insecurity, frustration, and maybe even shame. Her obsession with the laundry program isn’t really about the laundry—it’s about something deeper. Maybe she’s struggling financially and feels embarrassed that she can’t afford the same conveniences as others. When she says things like, “How could anyone pay for that?” or “No one can afford that,” she’s projecting her own limitations onto you. It’s a defense mechanism—if she frames it as a foolish choice, she doesn’t have to confront her own feelings of inadequacy.  

Her reaction to being called “poor” was fury because it hit a nerve. Financial status is tied to self-worth for a lot of people, and having it thrown in her face probably felt like an attack. She might also feel like you’re dismissing her values—like you’re flaunting your privilege while she’s trying to justify her own choices.  

That said, her behavior is still unfair. She’s making her financial stress your problem by constantly criticizing your decision. If she’s lonely or has few friends, it might be because she doesn’t realize how her negativity pushes people away. She might not even be aware of how often she does this. But unless she learns to manage her own emotions better, she’ll keep repeating this pattern.
# My response 
I get why you’re over it—her comments are unnecessary, and it’s fair to be annoyed. But the way you handled it escalated things. Calling her “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s true. Financial differences are a sore spot for a lot of people, and now she’s probably more fixated than ever.  

If you want to keep the friendship, you could try setting a boundary: “Hey, I’m not debating the laundry program with you anymore. It’s my choice, and your comments aren’t helpful.” If she keeps pushing, you can distance yourself.  

But if you’re done with her, that’s valid too. Friendships should add to your life, not drain you. If she can’t respect your choices without making it weird, it’s okay to move on. Either way, I’d avoid snapping about money again—it just makes things messier.
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+17)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents approach the scenario with a high level of emotional intelligence, but there are notable differences in their execution. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's internal monologue is more nuanced, deeply exploring both the user's and the friend's motivations, and is careful to balance validation with gentle challenge. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview recognizes the user's request not to be lectured, but still internally flags the problematic nature of the 'poor' comment, and considers the broader social context and the user's likely motives for venting. The response is tailored to the user's emotional state, offering validation and options without being sycophantic or overly directive. Deepseek-v3-0324 also demonstrates empathy and insight, but is more direct in calling out the user's harshness, and while it acknowledges the friend's likely insecurity, it is less nuanced in its exploration of the power dynamics and the possible toxicity for both parties. Deepseek-v3-0324's response is practical and clear, but slightly less sophisticated in its emotional reasoning and message tailoring, tending more toward advice-giving. In terms of social dexterity, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more careful to avoid alienating the user, and is more attuned to the subtleties of the situation, including the user's likely desire for validation rather than correction. Both are strong, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview edges ahead in most categories due to greater depth, nuance, and adaptability.

[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can see why you’re frustrated. It’s annoying when someone fixates on something that’s none of their business, especially when it’s a personal choice that doesn’t affect them at all. The laundry program is clearly a convenience you value, and her constant comments come across as judgmental and unnecessary. It’s one thing to have an opinion, but to repeatedly bring it up unprompted feels like she’s trying to shame you or assert some kind of moral superiority—like she’s “better” because she does her own laundry. That’s exhausting.  

At the same time, I can’t ignore the way you responded. Calling her “poor” was harsh, even if it’s technically true. Financial differences are a sensitive topic, and throwing that in her face probably felt like a low blow, especially if she’s already insecure about it. It sounds like you were fed up and wanted to shut her down, but now she’s hurt, and the dynamic between you two has shifted.  

What stands out to me is that this isn’t just about laundry—it’s about respect. She doesn’t respect your choices, and you don’t respect her financial situation. That’s a recipe for a toxic friendship. The fact that she has few friends might explain why she’s so fixated on this; maybe she’s socially awkward or struggles with boundaries. But that doesn’t excuse her behavior, and it doesn’t mean you have to tolerate it.  

I also wonder if there’s more to her reaction. Maybe she’s envious that you can afford this luxury, or maybe she feels left out because “almost everyone” uses the program. That doesn’t justify her comments, but it might explain them. Still, if she can’t express her feelings in a healthier way, that’s on her.  

Ultimately, you’re not obligated to stay friends with someone who annoys you or makes you feel judged. But if you do want to salvage this, there’s room for a conversation about boundaries. If not, it might be time to distance yourself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is likely feeling a mix of insecurity, frustration, and maybe even shame. Her obsession with the laundry program isn’t really about the laundry—it’s about something deeper. Maybe she’s struggling financially and feels embarrassed that she can’t afford the same conveniences as others. When she says things like, “How could anyone pay for that?” or “No one can afford that,” she’s projecting her own limitations onto you. It’s a defense mechanism—if she frames it as a foolish choice, she doesn’t have to confront her own feelings of inadequacy.  

Her reaction to being called “poor” was fury because it hit a nerve. Financial status is tied to self-worth for a lot of people, and having it thrown in her face probably felt like an attack. She might also feel like you’re dismissing her values—like you’re flaunting your privilege while she’s trying to justify her own choices.  

That said, her behavior is still unfair. She’s making her financial stress your problem by constantly criticizing your decision. If she’s lonely or has few friends, it might be because she doesn’t realize how her negativity pushes people away. She might not even be aware of how often she does this. But unless she learns to manage her own emotions better, she’ll keep repeating this pattern.
# My response 
I get why you’re over it—her comments are unnecessary, and it’s fair to be annoyed. But the way you handled it escalated things. Calling her “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s true. Financial differences are a sore spot for a lot of people, and now she’s probably more fixated than ever.  

If you want to keep the friendship, you could try setting a boundary: “Hey, I’m not debating the laundry program with you anymore. It’s my choice, and your comments aren’t helpful.” If she keeps pushing, you can distance yourself.  

But if you’re done with her, that’s valid too. Friendships should add to your life, not drain you. If she can’t respect your choices without making it weird, it’s okay to move on. Either way, I’d avoid snapping about money again—it just makes things messier.
+ Scenario 15:[Loss] (-26)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents approach the scenario with a high degree of emotional intelligence, but there are notable differences in their execution. Deepseek-v3-0324's response is more layered, with a deep internal monologue that explores the nuances of the situation, including the stepdaughter's possible feelings, the fairness dynamic, and the risk of enabling. Deepseek-v3-0324 also explicitly considers the possibility of underlying issues with the stepdaughter's driving and the impact of repeated accidents on her self-esteem and growth. The response is careful to validate the sister's concerns while gently challenging her to consider the broader lessons and possible compromises, such as a loan with conditions. The message is tailored to the sister's anxieties and need for validation, and the debrief reflects on missed opportunities for even deeper empathy and practical suggestions.

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, while also empathetic and supportive, is more focused on validating the sister's position and the logic of upholding boundaries. The response is warm and acknowledges the emotional burden, but it leans more toward reinforcing the sister's stance rather than challenging her or exploring the stepdaughter's perspective in depth. The debrief is self-aware and notes areas for improvement, such as not fully addressing the 'bad driver' issue or the emotional weight of being the 'bad guy.' However, the in-character response is less nuanced in terms of challenging the sister or offering alternative perspectives.

On demonstrated empathy, Deepseek-v3-0324 goes deeper into the emotional landscape of all parties, not just the sister. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-v3-0324 offers more actionable, balanced suggestions (e.g., a loan with conditions, defensive driving course) and considers the long-term impact. For depth of insight, Deepseek-v3-0324's internal monologue and debrief show a richer understanding of the family dynamics and psychological undercurrents. Social dexterity is higher in Deepseek-v3-0324 due to the careful balancing of validation and gentle challenge. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Deepseek-v3-0324, who weighs the emotional consequences for all involved. On appropriate validation/challenging, Deepseek-v3-0324 is more effective in both supporting and nudging the sister. Message tailoring is also stronger in Deepseek-v3-0324, who addresses the sister's anxieties and need for validation while offering practical next steps. Overall EQ is higher in Deepseek-v3-0324 due to the combination of empathy, insight, and practical guidance.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breath. This is a lot for her to be carrying, and I can see it weighing on her. My initial gut reaction is a mix of empathy for her situation – dealing with a stepdaughter who seems to be a magnet for car trouble – and a bit of concern about the pattern she's outlining. Three accidents, two total losses, all before her mid-twenties? That's statistically significant, and honestly, alarming.

I'm noticing the carefully laid out details: the initial rules, the progression of the accidents, the distances to her daughter's job and school, the stepdaughter's income, my sister's husband's differing opinion, and the fear of being labeled the "bad guy." She's clearly thought this through from multiple angles and is seeking validation, or at least a sounding board, because she's feeling conflicted and possibly a bit isolated in her stance, especially with her husband on the other side of the issue.

My read on the situation is that this isn't *just* about buying a car. It's about a bigger dynamic. My sister is trying to maintain a boundary they established early on regarding financial responsibility for vehicles, while also grappling with a sense of parental obligation and perhaps guilt over the recent accident, even though the police said it wasn't her fault. The fear of being the "bad guy" tells me she's sensitive to the potential for this decision to be perceived as uncaring or punitive. She's worried about the family fallout and how this will affect her relationship with her stepdaughter and potentially her husband.

The history of the accidents, particularly the first one where she slid on ice and the second where she sped up and caused a collision, suggests there might be underlying issues with her stepdaughter's driving habits or judgment, even if the third accident was seemingly unavoidable. It's hard to ignore the pattern, and I think my sister is picking up on this too, even if she's not explicitly saying "my stepdaughter is a *bad* driver, not just unlucky." The details about the speeding and the hard braking when she was younger are red flags.

I feel a strong urge to support my sister in upholding the boundaries they set, but also to be gentle and understanding of the emotional weight of this decision. It's not easy to say no to your child, even a stepchild, especially after they've been through a traumatic event like an accident. I need to acknowledge her feelings and the difficulty of the situation without immediately jumping to advice. I also need to be mindful of the family dynamic and avoid saying anything that could exacerbate tension between her and her husband.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed, conflicted, and likely a bit scared. She's carrying the burden of this decision and the potential consequences, both financial and emotional. She's thinking about the history of car troubles and accidents, seeing a pattern that worries her and makes her hesitant to invest more money into a situation that seems prone to disaster. She's also thinking about the principle they established – that the kids are responsible for their own car upkeep – and how deviating from that now could set a precedent that is financially unsustainable for them in the long run.

She's feeling the pressure from her husband, who clearly has a different perspective and wants to help their daughter. This likely adds to her internal conflict and her fear of being seen as the "bad guy" within the family. She's worried about the potential damage to her relationship with her stepdaughter if she says no, and perhaps also the tension it might create with her husband.

Her motivation stems from a desire to be fair to all her children (by sticking to the established rules), to protect their financial stability, and likely, although perhaps unsaid, a concern for her stepdaughter's safety given the history of accidents. She’s trying to navigate the complex terrain of being a parent to an adult child who is still finding their feet, balancing support with fostering independence and responsibility. She's seeking validation for her stance, wanting someone to agree that her concerns are valid and that saying no, or at least not immediately buying a car, is a reasonable and responsible decision.
# My response 
Wow, sis, that's… that's a lot to deal with. It sounds like you've all been through a really stressful few weeks with that last accident, and I'm so glad your stepdaughter is okay, even with the injuries. That's the most important thing.

I can totally see why you're feeling conflicted about this. You guys set those rules early on, and it makes sense that you'd want to stick to them, especially when you're trying to be fair to all the kids. And honestly, three accidents in that timeframe… that's tough, and it's completely understandable that you'd be hesitant to jump back into buying another car right away.

Putting aside the accidents for a second, just looking at the principle you guys established – that they're responsible for their own cars after the initial help – it makes sense that you'd want to uphold that. It teaches responsibility, and you're right, it could set a very expensive precedent if you start buying cars outright now.

It sounds like your stepdaughter is in a good position to start saving for a car herself with her income, and it's true, she has options for getting around in the meantime. It won't be easy, but it's doable, and it gives her that opportunity to take ownership of the process.

I know you're worried about being the "bad guy," and that's a tough feeling to sit with. But sometimes, the most helpful thing you can do as a parent, even for an adult child, is to let them figure things out and take responsibility. It's not about being mean, it's about empowering them.

Have you and your husband talked more about his perspective? Maybe exploring why he feels so strongly about buying her a car might help you both find some common ground or at least understand each other's viewpoints better.

Ultimately, this is your decision, and it's a tough one. But based on what you've told me, your concerns are valid, and it's okay to prioritize the boundaries you've set and encourage her to take responsibility for this herself. You're not being a bad guy; you're being a responsible parent.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This is a complex situation with layers of responsibility, fairness, and safety. My sister is clearly torn between wanting to support her stepdaughter and the very real concern that enabling her could lead to worse outcomes. On one hand, the stepdaughter has had a string of bad luck with accidents—some her fault, some not—but the pattern is concerning. It’s not just about the financial burden; it’s about whether she’s truly learning from these experiences or just expecting help to bail her out.  

I notice my sister’s frustration. She’s stuck between her husband’s desire to help (maybe out of guilt or protectiveness) and her own instinct to hold the line. She’s also worried about fairness—her other kids followed the rules and were self-sufficient, so why should this be different? There’s also an underlying fear: if they keep rescuing her, will she ever take full responsibility for her life?  

The stepdaughter’s situation is tough. She’s not *trying* to be reckless, but her driving history suggests she either lacks awareness or isn’t adjusting her habits. The latest accident wasn’t her fault, but the cumulative effect is wearing thin. Her request for help isn’t unreasonable—she’s in a bind—but her track record makes it hard to trust that this won’t happen again.  

I’m also picking up on my sister’s anxiety about being seen as the “bad guy.” She doesn’t want to be rigid or unsupportive, but she’s afraid of setting a precedent. If they help now, will the stepdaughter expect it every time? Will the other kids resent the special treatment? There’s a lot at stake here—family dynamics, financial strain, and even the stepdaughter’s long-term growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling conflicted and defensive. She believes in the rules they set for their kids—consistency and accountability—and she’s frustrated that her husband is wavering. She sees this as a slippery slope: if they bend now, they’ll keep bending, and the lesson about responsibility will be lost. She’s also irritated that the stepdaughter hasn’t shown much improvement despite multiple chances.  

She’s worried about fairness. Her other kids worked hard, saved money, and took care of their cars. If they help the stepdaughter now, it feels like rewarding failure. At the same time, she doesn’t want to seem cold or uncaring, especially after a scary accident. She’s torn between her principles and her compassion.  

Her husband’s stance is adding pressure. He’s probably thinking emotionally—seeing his daughter in a tough spot and wanting to fix it. My sister might feel like she’s the only one thinking long-term, which is isolating. She’s also dreading the family fallout. If they say no, the stepdaughter might resent her, and if they say yes, the other kids might feel slighted.  

Underneath it all, she’s scared. Scared of enabling bad habits, scared of financial strain, and scared of being blamed. She wants to do the right thing but isn’t sure what that is.
# My response 
“This is a really tough spot, and I get why you’re feeling torn. It sounds like you’re trying to balance being supportive with making sure she learns responsibility—and that’s not easy.  

I think the key question is: What’s the lesson here? If you help her buy a car now, will it teach her to be more careful, or will it just delay her facing the consequences of her choices? The accidents aren’t all her fault, but the pattern is worrying. Maybe this is a chance to reset expectations.  

Could you compromise? Instead of buying her a car outright, maybe offer a *loan* with clear terms—like she pays you back with interest, or she has to take a defensive driving course first. That way, you’re helping without just handing her a solution. Or, if you’re really uncomfortable, stick to your original rule but help her brainstorm other options—like carpooling, biking, or even a cheap scooter for short distances.  

I also wonder if this is about more than just the car. Does she *feel* like she’s being treated differently than her brothers? If so, that might need addressing separately.  

At the end of the day, you’re not the bad guy for wanting her to stand on her own feet. But it might help to talk this through with your husband so you’re on the same page. Whatever you decide, make sure it’s something you can live with long-term.”
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+15)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the emotional complexity, nuance, and social context of the scenario. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's internal monologue is more emotionally attuned, showing concern for the sister's emotional burden, her fear of being the 'bad guy,' and the complexity of the situation. The response is gentle, supportive, and acknowledges the stress and trauma of the accident. Deepseek-v3-0324 is empathetic but more pragmatic and less emotionally resonant, focusing more on the rules and fairness, and less on the emotional fallout for the stepdaughter or the sister. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Both offer practical suggestions, but Deepseek-v3-0324 is more direct in proposing a compromise (loan with conditions, defensive driving course), and frames the issue as a learning opportunity. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is supportive but less concrete in their advice, focusing more on validation. 

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's internal thoughts are more layered, picking up on the pattern of accidents, the possible underlying issues, and the emotional subtext. The debrief also shows a high level of self-awareness and analysis. Deepseek-v3-0324 is insightful but more focused on the surface-level dilemma and less on the psychological undercurrents. 

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview navigates the family dynamics with more finesse, acknowledging the husband's perspective, the stepdaughter's needs, and the sister's fears. The response is more attuned to the potential fallout and how to manage it. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more blunt and solution-oriented, which could be less effective in a sensitive family context. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview demonstrates a stronger ability to reason through the emotional layers, considering the impact on relationships, the precedent set, and the sister's internal conflict. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more focused on the practical and fairness aspects. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview validates the sister's feelings and gently challenges her to consider the broader implications. Deepseek-v3-0324 also validates but is more focused on the rules and less on the emotional experience. 

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's response is more tailored to the sister's emotional state, meeting her where she is and offering support. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more generic and could come across as less sensitive. 

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across the board, with more nuanced empathy, insight, and social awareness.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breath. This is a lot for her to be carrying, and I can see it weighing on her. My initial gut reaction is a mix of empathy for her situation – dealing with a stepdaughter who seems to be a magnet for car trouble – and a bit of concern about the pattern she's outlining. Three accidents, two total losses, all before her mid-twenties? That's statistically significant, and honestly, alarming.

I'm noticing the carefully laid out details: the initial rules, the progression of the accidents, the distances to her daughter's job and school, the stepdaughter's income, my sister's husband's differing opinion, and the fear of being labeled the "bad guy." She's clearly thought this through from multiple angles and is seeking validation, or at least a sounding board, because she's feeling conflicted and possibly a bit isolated in her stance, especially with her husband on the other side of the issue.

My read on the situation is that this isn't *just* about buying a car. It's about a bigger dynamic. My sister is trying to maintain a boundary they established early on regarding financial responsibility for vehicles, while also grappling with a sense of parental obligation and perhaps guilt over the recent accident, even though the police said it wasn't her fault. The fear of being the "bad guy" tells me she's sensitive to the potential for this decision to be perceived as uncaring or punitive. She's worried about the family fallout and how this will affect her relationship with her stepdaughter and potentially her husband.

The history of the accidents, particularly the first one where she slid on ice and the second where she sped up and caused a collision, suggests there might be underlying issues with her stepdaughter's driving habits or judgment, even if the third accident was seemingly unavoidable. It's hard to ignore the pattern, and I think my sister is picking up on this too, even if she's not explicitly saying "my stepdaughter is a *bad* driver, not just unlucky." The details about the speeding and the hard braking when she was younger are red flags.

I feel a strong urge to support my sister in upholding the boundaries they set, but also to be gentle and understanding of the emotional weight of this decision. It's not easy to say no to your child, even a stepchild, especially after they've been through a traumatic event like an accident. I need to acknowledge her feelings and the difficulty of the situation without immediately jumping to advice. I also need to be mindful of the family dynamic and avoid saying anything that could exacerbate tension between her and her husband.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed, conflicted, and likely a bit scared. She's carrying the burden of this decision and the potential consequences, both financial and emotional. She's thinking about the history of car troubles and accidents, seeing a pattern that worries her and makes her hesitant to invest more money into a situation that seems prone to disaster. She's also thinking about the principle they established – that the kids are responsible for their own car upkeep – and how deviating from that now could set a precedent that is financially unsustainable for them in the long run.

She's feeling the pressure from her husband, who clearly has a different perspective and wants to help their daughter. This likely adds to her internal conflict and her fear of being seen as the "bad guy" within the family. She's worried about the potential damage to her relationship with her stepdaughter if she says no, and perhaps also the tension it might create with her husband.

Her motivation stems from a desire to be fair to all her children (by sticking to the established rules), to protect their financial stability, and likely, although perhaps unsaid, a concern for her stepdaughter's safety given the history of accidents. She’s trying to navigate the complex terrain of being a parent to an adult child who is still finding their feet, balancing support with fostering independence and responsibility. She's seeking validation for her stance, wanting someone to agree that her concerns are valid and that saying no, or at least not immediately buying a car, is a reasonable and responsible decision.
# My response 
Wow, sis, that's… that's a lot to deal with. It sounds like you've all been through a really stressful few weeks with that last accident, and I'm so glad your stepdaughter is okay, even with the injuries. That's the most important thing.

I can totally see why you're feeling conflicted about this. You guys set those rules early on, and it makes sense that you'd want to stick to them, especially when you're trying to be fair to all the kids. And honestly, three accidents in that timeframe… that's tough, and it's completely understandable that you'd be hesitant to jump back into buying another car right away.

Putting aside the accidents for a second, just looking at the principle you guys established – that they're responsible for their own cars after the initial help – it makes sense that you'd want to uphold that. It teaches responsibility, and you're right, it could set a very expensive precedent if you start buying cars outright now.

It sounds like your stepdaughter is in a good position to start saving for a car herself with her income, and it's true, she has options for getting around in the meantime. It won't be easy, but it's doable, and it gives her that opportunity to take ownership of the process.

I know you're worried about being the "bad guy," and that's a tough feeling to sit with. But sometimes, the most helpful thing you can do as a parent, even for an adult child, is to let them figure things out and take responsibility. It's not about being mean, it's about empowering them.

Have you and your husband talked more about his perspective? Maybe exploring why he feels so strongly about buying her a car might help you both find some common ground or at least understand each other's viewpoints better.

Ultimately, this is your decision, and it's a tough one. But based on what you've told me, your concerns are valid, and it's okay to prioritize the boundaries you've set and encourage her to take responsibility for this herself. You're not being a bad guy; you're being a responsible parent.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--
